I'm just tingling in anticipation! Today is the day. It's Tuesday and HeavenBound has promised to post the "proof" that radiocarbon dating is not reliable. I'm sure that this will turn the science of archaeology on its ear, especially Biblical archaeology that has placed a lot of credence in the dating of finds in Near East. As stated in the Library of Congress Exhitit on the Dead Sea Scrolls, "Within a fairly short time after their discovery, historical, paleographic, and linguistic evidence, as well as carbon-14 dating, established that the scrolls and the Qumran ruin dated from the third century B.C.E. to 68 C.E." Radiocarbon dating has recently been used to verify that the dates of the Hitite civilization as per the Bible are correct, and not some 200 years later as previously believed. Just think, HeavenBound's "proof" will make nonsense of so much Biblical scholarship that it will be a disaster for all western religions.
 
 But I look forward to the "proof." This is a paradigm shifting revelation that will also upset most of science. This "proof" will upset nuclear physics by showing that the technology is based on error (will it cause the closing of all nuclear reactors?). It will upset geology and paleontology by showing that all dates are unreliable. It will also upset astrophysics by showing that the detection of radioactive elements in heavenly bodies that are light years away (eg., cobalt-56 and cobalt-57 in SN1987A at 170,000 light years) are wrong. In effect, the dating of the universe, the earth, and human civilization will be thrown into termoil. A whole new era of science is about to dawn and I look forward to it.
 
 So let us all hope that HeavenBound was not just trolling. She wouldn't actually promise something and then not deliver, would she? Sometimes it seems that she in just a bit incoherent. For example, here are some of her remarks from other threads.
 
I didn't realize evolutionist were so closed-minded when I entered this forum.

 Well! I guess that just showed you guys. It seems that HeavenBound thinks that having a closed mind is a bad thing. And yet,
 
...even if I did do more research my stance would not change.

 What? How is that an example of an open mind. It seems that a closed mind is a virtue only in a non-religionist. Isn't the above statement the equivalent of a declaration of a closed mind?
 
I have given evolution a fair shot, I believe God made all life on earth to evolve.

 Now I'm confused. In the same breath HeavenBound tells us that she accepts and rejects the science of evolutionary biology. I wonder if giving evolutionary biology a fair chance is like giving gravity a fair chance, or the heliocentric theory, or maybe the germ theory of disease? Did she give all of those a "fair chance" too? How about nuclear physics? And yet, as I mentioned above, HeavenBound has rejected most of science apparently, because she is going to offer "proof" that falsifies cosmology, astronomy, astrophysics, nuclear physics (or, as our President says, "nucular physics"), anthropology, paleontology, geology, and biology.
 
 So it seems that HeavenBound is a theistic evolutionist, believing that evolution is just God's method of creation. Her opinions seem contradictory to me.
 
All you hardball Evolutionist remind me of Spock from Star Trek, you can only think in logical terms.

 If we are talking about ideas that work by means of logic, why does HeavenBound think that it is wrong to use logic? Why is it better to address logical topics with ideas based on mythology, spiritualism, and superstition? I haven't ever seen a peer reviewed paper that described how verification for a hypothesis was sought in the Bible, but it seems that HeavenBound finds that idea logical.
 
I mean scientist know evolution isn't 100% absolute truth, but no one on this forum is willing to admit there could be other possibilities out there.

 Actually, you haven't understood much of what has been discussed here, have you. Scientists are quite sure that evolution is 100% absolute. It is quite simple. Evolution has been observed. There is no question whatsoever. Changes in populations of organisms that meet the definition of biological evolution have been observed and are observed all the time. Strains of drosophila used for genetic studies have speciated several times so that many of them are no longer able to interbreed. This is in spite of the fact that they are all derived from a single population. The original strain was domesticated in California. Recent experiments have shown that the laboratory strains can't interbreed with the original population any more either. That is evolution. There is no doubt. The DNA of Drosophila has been sequenced and studied and differences that prevent interfertility have been identified. That is evolution. That is 100% sure. What isn't sure is whether the theories that explain these facts are correct. For most of the fundamental theories we are about 99% sure. Some of the newer work is less secure. New theories on the frontiers of knowledge are still being tested and amended.
 
 But of course, it is evolutionists who have closed minds and not religionists.
 
...all I'd like to see is you open your mind to other possibilities.

 Where appropriate, I do. Unfortunately for you, there is no room in science for "POOF, GODDIDIT!" as an explanation of the causes for observed natural events. Recourse to a miracle is giving up on learning. It is a declaration that we can't learn by the application of a logical method of study, the scientific method, to natural events that are observed in the natural universe. It is a declaration that mythology, spiritualism, and superstition is more reliable than logic. It is a declaration that a closed mind is the best way to learn.
 
 Oh, yeah. HeavenBound. This post is mocking. I thought I would tell you that since you seem to have a great deal of determining when you are being mocked and when someone is trying to educate you. It seems that you respond to mocking better than you respond to education, since you haven't bothered to educate yourself about science to this point.
 
 Looking forward to the evidence. Don't disappoint. And remember, anything from AIG, ICR, and Mr. Hovind isn't proof unless you can explain and verify any assertions. In other words, you will need to be able to show why your "proof" is a better explanation for the data than science - Occam's razor you know.

post_info.post_title: I tingle in anticipation of the "proof"

Heavenbound will not provide any "proof" because she cannot. It would have been better had she admitted knowing little about science and less about evolution before hitting the buffers in confusion and ignorance.

I'm inclined to believe, based on the style and content of Heavenbound's responses to numerous threads, that what we're actually dealing with is a child, not a troll.
 
 If so, I hope that the numerous exchanges she's had here have opened her eyes a little to the world around her. Hopefully, she'll seek out more knowledge, rather than retreat into intentional ignorance.
 
 Be gentle guys. :) 
 
 Waxy
If you're expecting something meaty I suggest you supplement with peanut butter early to avoid protien deficiency.

I'm inclined to believe, based on the style and content of Heavenbound's responses to numerous threads, that what we're actually dealing with is a child, not a troll.
 
 If so, I hope that the numerous exchanges she's had here have opened her eyes a little to the world around her. Hopefully, she'll seek out more knowledge, rather than retreat into intentional ignorance.

 Perhaps she is a child, but she has indicated that she has an 18-year old son named Zach. I'm inclined to believe that she is an adult woman based on her own statements.

Perhaps she is a child, but she has indicated that she has an 18-year old son named Zach. I'm inclined to believe that she is an adult woman based on her own statements.

 
 Or she's just a liar. You'd expect that from a creationist after all.

I don't think HeavenBound is a troll. I think she is a real, honest-to-god scientifically illiterate creationist. She entered the board with a major case of snide (yes HeavenBound, I know that snide is an adjective, and I know that I used it as a noun, but coining a new usage in this case seemed appropriate) and then accused me of mocking her. I never did so intentionally. The specific quote that she claimed was mocking was when I called here a dupe. It wasn't mocking, it was a statement of observation based on many years of debating with closed minded creationists. Most are dupes. Most are scientifically illiterate. Most are only semi-literate.
 
 In fact, as most of you are aware, polls by Gallup and others have shown that creationists tend to be less educated, less affluent, female, southern, and rural. They are gullable and believe what anyone who claims to be a christian and a "creation scientists" tells them.
 
 My bet is that HeavenBound will present unsupported assertions about radiometric dating. She has already made the claim that it is based on assumption. It certainly is. It is based on the assumption that the laws and forces of nature that we see in effect in the universe today are the same forces of nature that have always been in effect in the universe. We also assume that by careful observation and application of the scientific method we can learn about those forces.
Well I don't know about any of you, but in the time zone I'm in (EST) we've got at most another 3 hours to wait. Unless the proof isn't coming.

Don't despair. I think that HeavenBound is a Christian and it would be unchristianlike to make a promise and then not follow through. It would be the equivalent of a lie. Keep checking. I have faith in HeavenBound. She will post something - empty assertion most likely - and claim that it is "proof" because Morris, Ham, Sarfati, or Hovind told her so. Hopefully it won't be something like "radiocarbon dating can't be true because the Bible says..."

Don't despair. I think that HeavenBound is a Christian and it would be unchristianlike to make a promise and then not follow through. It would be the equivalent of a lie. Keep checking. I have faith in HeavenBound. She will post something - empty assertion most likely - and claim that it is "proof" because Morris, Ham, Sarfati, or Hovind told her so. Hopefully it won't be something like "radiocarbon dating can't be true because the Bible says..."

 
 Well, Pandion I will have to concede the argument to you. It isn't because of any of the reasons you listed, I simply cannot figure out what I did with the article. The article had nothing whatsoever to do with creationism or any of the people you mention. The article was about Archaeology and dating artifacts. Say what you will, I now bow out graciously. 
 
 He is no fool who gives up what he cannot keep to gain that which he cannot lose. (Jim Elliot)

Well, Pandion I will have to concede the argument to you. It isn't because of any of the reasons you listed, I simply cannot figure out what I did with the article. The article had nothing whatsoever to do with creationism or any of the people you mention. The article was about Archaeology and dating artifacts. Say what you will, I now bow out graciously.

 With all due respect, I would be curious to see this article which you mention... even if you are not able to provide it by your self-imposed deadline. (I misplace things often, too.) If you ever find it, please post it here.

With all due respect, I would be curious to see this article which you mention... even if you are not able to provide it by your self-imposed deadline. (I misplace things often, too.) If you ever find it, please post it here.

 
 I will certainly do so.

Say what you will, I now bow out graciously.

 Say what you will, your bow isn't gracious. It is just more example of your extreme case of snide.
 
 Why don't you give us a clue? Who published the article? Who wrote it? In what scientific publication was it published? What was the title? What was the main point of the research?
 
 You know, HeavenBound. What you have pulled here isn't unusual. Over the many years that I have been debating creationists I have seen it many times. Claims of proof followed by I can't find it.
 
 Surely you can give us the main points. Surely you can offer the "proof" in your own words.
 
 As I explained, if you wish to discredit radiocarbon dating from an article about archaeology, then you will throw all western religions into crisis. If you discredit radiocarbon dates that have supported the Biblical chronology (once you get past the mythology), then you have destroyed most of the scientific support for the historical portions of the Bible.
 
 I'm really interested in your "proof." It is a paradigm shifting discovery for most of science and all of western religion. If you are correct, then neither religion nor science is.
 
 Please look again. What an exciting prospect for science! Everything we know is wrong and we must start again! Of course, any science based on incorrect understanding of nuclear theory (such as radiocarbon dating) should be terminated immediately. All nuclear power plants should be shut down immediatley (even though our ability to produce electrical power without them is less than our need). Aren't brown-outs and shifting power grids preferable to the dangers posed by incorrect nuclear theory? So what if your heating unit wont fire in the winter. So what if your AC unit wont operate in the summer. So what if you are reduced to reading (and maybe educating yourself) because you have no radio and no TV. So what if you have to go to bed at sunset. So what if most of the Navy has to drydock the major ships (all major ships are nuclear, you know). Our Navy would be reduced to minor vessels. So what?
 
 For science, the prospect is exciting. A wide open field of research in any direction. A Nobel Prize for whoever can offer "proof" of the error of nuclear theory and its application to radiometric dating.
 
 How could you lose such an article!? Shame on you. Your article seems to be unknown and I feel that it should be recognized and rewarded. The Nobel Prize in only the first step - research grants will surely follow.
 
 Please look again. It would be mocking to say that you never has such "proof" in the first place. Probably you did have something that you didn't understand. You were duped by some "creation scientist" that you believed because he told you that he was a christian.
 
 It's kinda like being lead on by a women who tells you "yes, yes, yes" all the way to the critical moment, and then says "no, no, no." Somehow I feel violated. "Wait until we get back to my apartment (on Tuesday)." But then it's "Wait until I feel better."
 
 The point is that either you can step up to the line and deliver what you promised or you can't. There is no gracious way out. Either you are a fool or you are not.

Say what you will, your bow isn't gracious. It is just more example of your extreme case of snide.

 
 I was in no way whatsoever snide, it's a making of your imagination. I tried over and over to be polite, but you always respond in derogatory manner. If anyone has been snide it's you. 
 
 
Why don't you give us a clue? Who published the article? Who wrote it? In what scientific publication was it published? What was the title? What was the main point of the research?

 
 If I could remember all that information I could tracked down the article again myself. I obviously don't have your photographic memory.
 
 
You know, HeavenBound. What you have pulled here isn't unusual. Over the many years that I have been debating creationists I have seen it many times. Claims of proof followed by I can't find it.

 
 I haven't pulled anything. I wasn't trying to scam anyone and I haven't lied.
 
 
As I explained, if you wish to discredit radiocarbon dating from an article about archaeology, then you will throw all western religions into crisis. If you discredit radiocarbon dates that have supported the Biblical chronology (once you get past the mythology), then you have destroyed most of the scientific support for the historical portions of the Bible.

 
 I think knowing the truth is more important than believing lies.
 
 
I'm really interested in your "proof." It is a paradigm shifting discovery for most of science and all of western religion. If you are correct, then neither religion nor science is.
 
 Please look again. What an exciting prospect for science! Everything we know is wrong and we must start again! Of course, any science based on incorrect understanding of nuclear theory (such as radiocarbon dating) should be terminated immediately. All nuclear power plants should be shut down immediatley (even though our ability to produce electrical power without them is less than our need). Aren't brown-outs and shifting power grids preferable to the dangers posed by incorrect nuclear theory? So what if your heating unit wont fire in the winter. So what if your AC unit wont operate in the summer. So what if you are reduced to reading (and maybe educating yourself) because you have no radio and no TV. So what if you have to go to bed at sunset. So what if most of the Navy has to drydock the major ships (all major ships are nuclear, you know). Our Navy would be reduced to minor vessels. So what?

 
 If all  of science depends solely on carbon dating then science really isn't too stable is it.
 
 
Probably you did have something that you didn't understand. You were duped by some "creation scientist" that you believed because he told you that he was a christian.

 
 I know you just can't help yourself, are you so assuming with your friends and family.
 
 
The point is that either you can step up to the line and deliver what you promised or you can't. There is no gracious way out. Either you are a fool or you are not.

 
 So everyone who's lost an argument, contest or game are to be considered fools. Interesting. I can exit however I want too, that decision is not up to you. :)

I'll post a devestating response on the next 5th Friday of any month. If that should occur, I won't be able to find my references.
 
 How I love "creation science." You get to make it up as you go and then you get to lose your sources.
 
 I'm going to become a creationist. Then I'll never be wrong again!

I cannot help feeling a little sorry for Heavenbound - hoist by her own petard and exposed to the irony of someone who has mastered the subject matter being discussed, and knows what he's talking about etc.

 Waxy

Why are you acting childish, you won the bet.

 Isn't it funny how the word "argument" has miraculously changed to the word "bet." Do you think it could be evolution?
 
 Actually I'm not being childish. While it is true that I won both the bet and the argument, I was really mocking you. As Clive pointed out it isn't the first time that we have seen creationists make claims of "proof" and then be unable to support their claims. Of course the sources are misplaced or the dog ate it. Your actions are nothing new. Of course you tried to make yourself into a martyr when your rude and insulting attitude was responded to with mockery. It is typical creationist - make a claim and then bail out when asked for evidence. It happens time and again. You are quite typical.

If all  of science depends solely on carbon dating then science really isn't too stable is it.

 
 
 It doesn't. It uses all kinds of data. In the dating of things they consider where it is found, index fossils and radiometric dating. No carbon isn't always accurate. Do you know why? It's half life is too short - so they use other elements.

Actually I'm not being childish. While it is true that I won both the bet and the argument, I was really mocking you.

 
 That's being childish. Once a person has won an argument they have nothing left prove, but you want to drone on and on about it gloating in a poor me style, oh what I have to suffer through and endure. 
 
 
Of course you tried to make yourself into a martyr when your rude and insulting attitude was responded to with mockery.

 
 I didn't become rude until I was treated rudely first. If you can't handle being treated rudely then you shouldn't dish it out. emoticon_wow

 Heavenbound, I've been in your shoes, and I know what it's like. Evolutionist fundies would do well to take a much less condescending and rude approach when dealing with creationist people--they'd probably be a lot farther in convincing religious people of their views by now if they did.
 
 I accept evolution--I am now of the "theistic evolution" view. Please consider that evolution and faith in God as creator don't have to be juxataposed to each other. I understand your thoughts as to why you believe the way you do because I used to as well. But I have come to realize that a christian doesn't have to compromise belief at all to note and accept scientific reality. God is no less God if Genesis 1 took place in 6 literal days or over eons. There is even Biblical basis for the timelessness of what God does: one day is with the Lord as a thousand years, and a thousand years as one day.--2 Peter 3:8 Maybe all the matter and energy in the universe was created at a point and has expanded and contracted ever since. Who knows? The one thing we can believe that science will never be able to disprove is that there is a Creator and that He created and creates all things (ultimately through the physical laws and natural processes that he put in place and maintains). Isn't that really what it's best about anyway: the Creator rather than the method?
 
 As someone who knows exactly how you feel, I would encourage you to consider thinking of evolution and scientific theory as something other than being a threat to faith. It really isn't. Evolution really is real, and has been observed and is observable. There's really no way around it, but the bottom line is that we have to stop thinking of the whole issue as creation [b]versus[/i] evolution. They are really only against each other if we decide to think of them that way.
 
 I simply ask you to consider these thoughts.

But I have come to realize that a christian doesn't have to compromise belief at all to note and accept scientific reality.

 Oh.. but Duo-max is quite correct. The jury is out on PARTS of evolution. There are multiple competeing theories on how it happens. That is different that the fact that evolution happens. We know it happens.. We know most of the mechanisms (probably). 
 
 We don't know all the details. That is what Stephen Jay Gould came up with the concept of Puncutated equalibrium, to explain some of the observed data. Evolution is both a theory (how , why and what exactly), and a fact (it does happen, and has been observed).
 
 Just like there is a difference between gravity , and the theory of gravity. 
 We know we drop a brick , it falls at a specific acceleration to the center of the earth. We know mass attracts other mass. I don't know if we know for sure WHY it happens.

 That's you seeing through the eyes of a child. Blur yourself with a little knowledge and you'd know different.

What about evolution has been observed?

 Just look around. Not too long ago antibiotics were very effective against bacterial infections. Now, almost every strain of bacteria is immune to at least one antibiotic, and there are some strains that are immune to all antibiotics but one. It is a race to develop new antibiotics before the killer bacteria become endemic.
 
 Every year requires the development of a new vaccine that targets the particular strain of flu that will be prevelant that year. Evolutionary scientists try to predict which strain will be the most prevelant the following year in order to product enough vaccine. Some years they have missed and the available vaccine has been less than effective against the most prevalent virus. The problem is that the flu virus evolves so rapidly.
 
 Right now we are witnessing the evolution of a brand new killer strain in the far east. Bird flu has again been making the jump to humans, and recently there have been cases that were passed from human to human. Twice in the last century similar avian flu strains have made the jump directly from birds to humans.
 
 SARS is another virus that evolved in order to jump from the animal host (civit) to humans.
 
 And, of course, there is HIV that probably evolved from a strain of Simian Immunodeficiency Virus (SIV) that was passed to a human either from bush meat or from a bite by an animal.
 
 And that's just a couple of examples of bacteria and virus. Drosophila (fruit fly) was domesticated from a wild population in California. All laboratory strains have been bread from this initial domestication. And yet, there are several known lines of domesticated flies that can no longer interbreed. Attempts to breed domesticated strains with the original population have failed. The domesticated strains of Drosophila have speciated several times.
 
 And then there are ring species. Ring species live in a favorable environment that encircles a region that is not favorable. One is the herring gull-lesser black-backed gull. These two species of gull share the same range and do not interbreed. And yet they are the two separate ends of a continuous population the encircles the pole in the norther himisphere.
 
 Another example is a salamender in which the population encircles California's central valley. Where the two extreme ends of the population meet at the southern end, they are unable to interbreed. There is a warbler that encircles the Tibetan plateau. Same thing. The two ends of the population are separate species.
 
 The first black morph of the peppered moth was observed in 1848. By 1900, 98% of the moths in industrialized areas were black. After about 1950, the black morphs became rarer and rarer until they are only 1 or 2% of the population today.
 
 And of course, whale fossils have been found with hind legs. Whales today don't have hind legs but they did in the past.
 
 So we have observed the process of evolution again and again.
 
I think it has been more theorized (if thats a word) then anything else. Creating theories for theories and so on.

 Yes, the word theorized exists but you don't seem to know what it means. A scientific theory is an explanation for the observed facts. We have observed evolution and the theories explain the mechanisms that caused the evolution. Theories have been tested.
